awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nucleobase-Modified Peptide Nucleic Acid (PNA) for Sequence Selective Triple-Helical Recognition of Non-Coding Ribonucleic Acid (RNA)
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding a collaborative effort between Professors Eriks Rozners (Binghamton University) and James A. MacKay (Elizabethtown College). The research develops new methods for molecular recognition of biologically-significant, non-coding ribonucleic acid (RNA). The majority of cellular RNA consists of non-coding RNAs that play important roles in regulating gene expression even though these processes are not fully understood. Selective recognition, imaging, and functional regulation of such RNAs are useful for fundamental studies and practical applications in biotechnology. The project expands interdisciplinary, collaborative research across traditional institutional boundaries. The project establishes a bridge for Elizabethtown College (a primarily undergraduate institution) students to transition from undergraduate studies to advanced graduate studies at a research university.  Undergraduate students, especially women, minorities and first generation college students, participate in the project. The project also contributes to improving STEM education. 

The development of sequence selective RNA binders is important for understanding the biochemistry of non-coding RNAs. Such binders may  impact fundamental RNA biology and practical applications in biotechnology and synthetic biology. This collaborative study is developing new peptide nucleic acid (PNA) nucleobases that enable recognition of the entire Hoogsteen face of Watson-Crick and non-canonical base pairs of double-stranded RNA. The properties of the novel nucleobases are optimized using synthetic organic chemistry to enable recognition of any sequence of double-stranded RNA. This approach may solve a long-standing problem in molecular recognition of RNA and enables a variety of applications. Examples of such applications are: imaging and functional control of regulatory RNA, designer riboswitches for synthetic biology, and inhibition of biologically-important RNA for fundamental studies.

por.por_cntn:
RNA has a host of diverse functions despite being most renowned as a mediator between DNA and proteins in the central dogma of molecular biology. While only ~2% of the human genome codes for protein, between 70-90% of human DNA is transcribed into noncoding RNA (ncRNA) and new functions of ncRNA continue to be discovered. Furthermore, ncRNA adopts defined tertiary structure including double helical regions that are ripe for molecular recognition. This project involved the development of new synthetic oligonucleotide nucleobases designed for formation of triple helices with double helical RNA in a sequence specific manner. These nucleobases are incorporated into peptide nucleic acids (PNAs), and applications of this binding mode are expected to afford opportunities for fundamental discoveries in biotechnology and medicine through the recognition and functional modulation of RNA.

The work resulting from this grant was enhanced significantly by the broader impacts where we used a cross institutional collaboration between Elizabethtown College (EC), a primarily undergraduate institution, and Binghamton University (BU), a research institution to establish a bridge between undergraduate learning and graduate school. Though a senior-level Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience, called Integrated Laboratory (I-lab), dozens of Elizabethtown College undergraduate students were exposed to the research project. I-Lab students generated new ideas, performed literature searches, tested their ideas in the lab, and worked with both PIs and BU graduate students to advance the project. Several outcomes from the I-Lab seeded ideas that ultimately were developed into publishable results related to the scientific merit. Albeit at a smaller scale, but toward a broader audience, a similar approach was incorporated into a 5-week research experience in the sophomore level Organic Chemistry laboratory course. In this course, over 40 students were introduced to the line of research and learned about applied synthetic chemistry.

Further, for three years, we hosted a three-day Winter RNA workshop at BU where EC students visited BU, learned more about RNA and the research project, and interacted with BU chemistry faculty and students. The workshop was a key professional development opportunity for EC students affording them the chance to experience a graduate school environment by meeting with faculty, interacting with graduate students, and learning new techniques and procedures in hands-on workshops. It was attended by about 10 students per year and was unanimously praised for the unique opportunity it provided. In all, through all the above-mentioned activities, we exposed over 70 undergraduates to this line of research, many of whom were women, minorities and/or first-generation college students. The work resulted in three undergraduates co-authoring scientific publications, and dozens of undergraduate presentations at local, regional, and national meetings. Two Elizabethtown College alumni joined the PhD in chemistry program at BU and many others matriculated to other graduate and professional schools of their choosing.

This funding period resulted in several significant scientific discoveries. We reported the first NMR structure of a PNA:RNA2 triple helix using 2-amino pyridine (M)-modified PNA. This established the proposed Hoogsteen hydrogen-bonding of base triples in the triple helix. The NMR studies also revealed that the PNA amide hydrogen-bonds to phosphate residues in the RNA backbone. This confirms the hypothesis that PNA is a better match for RNA (existing in the A-form) than DNA (B-form) and further support the use PNA in biological systems without off-target effects on DNA.

We also prepared several extended nucleobases for incorporation into PNA. Several first generation extended nucleobases showed only moderate affinity for triplex formation, yet we designed and prepared a series of extended nucleobase monomers through isoorotic acid derived amides that showed improved binding to adenine compared to the commonly employed thymidine (T) base. In this study, we reported that four consecutive modifications led to enhanced stabilization due to a cooperative effect. This later result demonstrates promise for use of multiple consecutive extended nucleobases in PNA for RNA recognition.

All together, we have improved on PNA as an important tool for double helical RNA recognition. This tool has multiple applications in science and suggests that our synthetic PNA can be utilized for important new discoveries of functional and structural importance of RNA.
